column1: [1] [1] is known within the philosophy of mind and artificial intelligence fields for his work on natural language using the [2] program, developed in 1968-1970, which involves the user giving instructions to a computer operating in a "[3] [3]".
[1] is an early natural language processing computer program created from 1964 to 1966[1] at the MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory by [2] [2].
column5: Created to demonstrate the superficiality of communication between humans and machines, ELIZA simulated conversation by using a "pattern matching" and substitution methodology that gave users an illusion of understanding on the part of the program, but had no built in framework for contextualizing events.

column1: The premise of symbolic NLP is well-summarized by [1] [1]'s [2] [2] experiment: given a collection of rules (e.g., a Chinese phrasebook, with questions and matching answers), the computer emulates natural language understanding (or other NLP tasks) by applying those rules to the data it confronts.

The 1980s and early 1990s mark the heyday of symbolic methods in NLP. Focus areas of the time included research on rule-based parsing (e.g., the development of [1] as a computational operationalization of generative grammar), morphology (e.g., two-level morphology), semantics (e.g., [2] algorithm), reference (e.g., within Centering Theory) and other areas of natural language understanding (e.g., in the [3] Structure Theory).
